job_title: Anonymous/Employee in Boca Raton, FL
pros: The insurance and retirement is the best and potentially only bonus. Coworkers share comradery because frustrations are shared, but at least you're not alone. Low difficulty level work. Diversity.
cons: I've worked in multiple departments and found the same issues throughout. I never felt supported or like any of the teams I was on had my back. There are deep seeded issues that will never be solved because of the bureaucracy in place. Illogical and out of date practices are implemented and when you question why you're told "that's how we've always done it", with no wiggle room for improvement or better practices. Raises are nonexistent and the pay is lower than standard across the board. 'Figure it out yourself' mentality from management. Nobody above me knew how to do my job so there was no support when I ran into issues. Poor management. Red tape everywhere and bureaucratic issues between departments. No support from department to department. Issues aren't handled efficiently, the students and staff don't feel supported by the administration when matters of racism and core value issues come up. Specifically a situation where a student made racist and hateful remarks on social media, was found out, and continued his enrollment at the school after being allowed to sit in on the 'peer meeting' designed to hold him accountable, for which he was unapologetic.

job_title: Grad Student Employee in Boca Raton, FL
pros:
Most student affairs positions have competitive pay - $15/hr, 20 hrs/week - and many of the director-level staff and their teams are quite nice to be around and work with.
Some offices/departments have tuition waivers in addition to pay.
Most of the work is not very difficult and can be great for professional development and autonomy - seems like lots of supervisors generally trust their employees to get work done.
Staff/team meetings and 1-on-1s have generally not been a headache, some are even cool or great.
There are some truly excellent student organizations and Black fraternities and sororities.
There are basically always opportunities to find new things to do or new ways to do things.
cons:
It's a public university, so the FL Board of Governors and FL Governor make a lot of rules that make no sense but are basically impossible to get around. This is tough to put up with if you aren't a fascist.
The most senior level staff at the institution, particularly the Executive/C Suite and the Board of Trustees (not staff, but you get the idea) are old, white, cis men who put on a good show of allyship but don't do the work when it matters.
The profs are underpaid and adjuncts don't have good job security.
Pike (nefarious fraternity) is on campus.
Some supervisors/managers/director-level staff aren't receptive to offering raises or simply don't have the positions/budget to help employees progress. Some staff see increases in responsibility but no increases in pay, leading them to leave the institution.

pros: Since it's a State Government job, it's got pretty good benefits (health insurance, vacation & sick time, low cost classes, participates in a variety of employee discount programs at various online retailers).
cons:
Because it's a State Government job, there are things that happen beyond the control of anyone at the University (budget cuts, etc).  
While there are University policies, there is a lot of fluctuation in how there are implemented and observed, if they even are, depending on what department and office you work in.  This is usually a Con, but can sometimes be a Pro.

Have to pay for employee parking, on a sliding scale depending on your salary (averages around $100 per year for low level employees with one vehicle).

review_title: Great and knowledgeable faculty, though some improvements would be welcome.

job_title: in Boca Raton, FL
pros:
Mathematics department at FAU (Boca Raton campus) must be considered as one of the best departments at FAU. Most of the professors have either had their own Ph.D in mathematics/computer-science or have worked at well-known places like Harvard, Princeton, Waterloo, Rutgers, OSU, Cornell, MIT etc. Being trained at these palces, one can see the high quality of education that is provided by them at any level of graduate course. 

Someone once told me, to do a good research, the key point is your advisor. One might not like the area at times, but a good advisor can make you like it. I highly recommend mathematics dept. at FAU for graduate studies. Not only one can see themselves rise and learn (not just about mathematics but about industry related applied work among the humble company of these professors), but also enjoy their time in warm sunny florida among very international/national fellow grads.
cons: Never buy the health insurance from F A U, buy it from some outside company if you ever have to.

review_title: Chemistry TA for General Chemisty 1, 2, and Health Sciences
job_title: Teacher Assistant in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Being in a university environment, you are surrounded with people who enjoy learning and teaching others. That being said, the job was always exciting, due to the fact that you can really shine as an individual in front of a class, as long as you make sure the students are being safe. TAs are exempt from paying Social Security and have their portion contributed to TIAA Cref, which is a nice savings perk. However, unless you are a student there, you do not get health benefits. I never found the job to be so stressful that I couldn't maintain my own sanity outside of the workplace.
cons: There is very little room for advancement, unless you are seeking an advanced degree. Being a TA if exceptionally beneficial if you are looking to advance in a Masters or PhD program, as the school offers stipends and tuition reimbursement (as do most schools if you are seeking a PhD in a scientific field).

review_title: Supervisors are incompetent, shop online during work hours and humiliate to intimidate.
job_title: Academic Coordinator in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Loved working with students for over eight years, they made my tenure "doable." Good colleagues/coordinators, it truly becomes misery loves company. Facility in Boca is good, if one ever gets out of their office to enjoy!
cons: Absolutely NO support from supervisors. Humiliation, gossip, lack of raise or promotions given to extremely diligent and creative workers. Favortism is constant for those in "good" with deans. Working conditions are a joke. Cannot even leave to use the restroom without director yelling "where is everyone?" There is no time to train, though responsibilities are continually added [on]. Tuition remission exists, yet supervisors will not approve time off for courses. I have no regrets in this experience, yet suggest NO one work here, the focus is upon online courses, cutting salaries of middle level coordinators and instructors and ultimately, the students are losing out, we have too many students to serve!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Boca Raton, FL
pros:
Really nice campus, lots of fun things to do, always events going on. The campus is really nice to walk around in and has a lot of places where you can take a blanket/towel and chill or have a picnic. The gym is GREAT. Really diverse campus with people from all walks of life. They also have high schoolers there since they have a dual program for them but they for the most part don't get in the way of an university experience. The student organizations like SAVI are fun to work with. The medical and dental places have really nice professions working there too. Same with their Counseling Center. They really care about you and want to help you. There are plenty of job opportunities as a student so always look for those, especially if you live on campus. It's a nice way to help pay for classes/textbooks or other expenses. But tread carefully with your bosses/supervisors!

There are a lot of food places close by that's accessible by food. The mall is very close too. The ones higher in the hierarchy, like the provost and others, have always been fun and friendly every time I ran into them at events or on campus. The Jaffe Center is beautiful and the people working there are so passionate. Definitely check out their events and classes if you can. The department I worked for had really nice staff and the faculty for the most part were really friendly too. Can't say if that's how it is for other departments but for the most part they were nice.
cons: After graduating, they don't really care as much about you other than calling you for alumni donations. For example, former professors won't respond to your email and if you're asking for advice you probably won't get any. Basically if you're not a paying student, they don't really bother with you. The career centers will assist you as much as they can but I would suggest going to several of them to get a good range of advice since I've received inaccurate/bad information before but it got corrected when I saw another career advisor.  As with other universities, the academic advisors (especially for undergrad) are mostly unhelpful. I've received bad information several times and ended up taking classes I didn't need to and ended up not getting the minor I wanted. One of my friends ended up being coerced into changing her major because her advisor was focused on making her switch her major instead of helping her figure out the best course of action. The parking is horrendous as is the drive to actually get into the campus so always give yourself a lot of extra time and find different ways to enter into the campus.  Class options can be limited sometimes and they make taking classes at another college extremely difficult. For example, if you're try to be a transient student and take classes at BC because FAU doesn't offer the class at the semester you NEED to take it or because the class at BC is the same but cheaper (obviously for lower level courses) , they'll basically deny you no matter what. I think it also depends on "who you know" sometimes but can't say for sure obviously. Students can be very clique-y sometimes so it's harder to make friends since most people seem to want to stick with the friends they made in high school that also happens to go to FAU.

NO ONE gets pay raises.  3 years without a raise of any kind except a "title" promotion which meant more work for same pay.

review_title: Battle of the Stupids: This porridge is too lazy, this porridge is too rude, this porridge is too sad and depressing
job_title: Coordinator, Computer Applications in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Perhaps if you were writing a book of autobiographical short stories about the tragically comedic pitfalls of the public sector and state university employment, FAU could be a gold mine for a New York Times #1 Best Seller like I Hope They Serve Beer In Hell by Tucker Max. But then again you would have to have a pretty sick sense of humor as well as thick skin to endure your role in these experiences. You really cannot make this stuff up otherwise.
cons:
As some others have stated, this place is bad for your health especially if you are in the earlier portion of your career or have any bit of aspiration -- FAU is a morale killer and motivation murderer (unless it's to quit and seek any other form of employment as I did -- my only regret is that I didn't do it sooner)

Management is very mean and the environment is a very nasty place, and I don't care how tough you are, it will beat you to your knees and keep you there permanently if you let it. I saw too many people that appear to have lost something along their way feeling stuck in their place here. At first I didn't understand why they were like that or why they stayed until I started accumulating a few years finding myself getting caught up in the same daily grind rat race. Favors for favors. Nepotism. Good ol' boy impropriety. Complete absence of accountability. The list goes on.
